definition:
Let $V$ be a vector space of dimension $n$ over a field $K$. If
$(b_1,\,\ldots,\,b_n)$ is a basis of $V$, then any element $v$ of $V$
can be uniquely expressed in the form
$$v \;=\; \xi_1b_1\!+\ldots+\!\xi_nb_n$$ with
$\xi_1,\,\ldots,\,\xi_n \in K$. The $(\xi_1,\,\ldots,\,\xi_n)$ is called
the *coordinate vector* of $v$ with respect to the basis in question.
The scalars $\xi_i$ are the *coordinates* (or the *components* of $v$).

It’s evident that the correspondence
$$v \;\mapsto\; (\xi_1,\,\ldots,\,\xi_n)$$ provides a linear isomorphism
between the vector space $V$ and the vector space formed by the
Cartesian product $K^n$.
